text: and welcome to the webcast today new mobile push notifications from Amazon simple notification services our
presenter today is John toell Senior product manager at Amazon web services
at the same time we're pleased to have um probably Muma business development manager with us to answer audience
questions John you have the floor thanks and good morning uh in addition to being
a senior product manager for our messaging products I manage the simple notification service that we're going to
speak about today and by the time we're done you're going to learn why crossplatform mobile
push notifications were painful in the past and how SNS mobile push makes them
easy scalable and cost- effective so to get started let's review
what push notifications are and how they work customers tell us they use mobile
push notifications to extend the experience of their app when the app keeps running in the cloud even when
their customers May close it on their specific devices they use them to drive
engagement and so you may have seen these for a game that you may be that you may be playing or a flight update
for a flight that you may have checked into and some points to knowe users opt in to receive mobile push notifications
they're short they're designed to catch the attention or provide a stream of
information and they are delivered to a specific app on a specific device
now as from a developer's perspective when you send a mobile push notification
you address that message to the particular app on the particular device that you'd like to send and that message
is truly pushed in the sense that the user doesn't have to check for it and the device doesn't have to pull for it
but rather it arrives quite quickly to the specific device and can pop up on
the user's lock screen in order to accomplish this trick
of truly pushing the messages to the user's connected device each Major
mobile platform maintains a push notification service that maintains
persistent connections with the devices that it owns and so as a developer when
you address a message to a particular device you rather than sending it directly to the device and rather than
maintaining that particular connection to the particular device you instead send your notification to the platform
service and the platform service relays it to the device and this makes your life easier
because you don't have to do the work of maintaining tens of millions of
simultaneous connections and you don't need to hold on to messages in order to
deliver them when the device may be off for example if your user is on a plane but in addition to making your
life easier it involves some extra complexity that Developers today have to deal
with for example the platform Services ask you to maintain a list of all the
tokens of all the devices that you have been authorized to send mobile push notifications
to and when a device is disabled or when a user deletes your app or if the token
that represents that app on that device changes if it rotates you are expected
as a developer to Pro actively update your own database so that you can
correctly address the list of devices that are live and when you start to scale up to a
large number of devices this gets tricky developers tell us they try to avoid this step but actually it's really
important because if you don't do it correctly your messages may be delayed they may not get where they're going and
so it's important but really painful now we've spoken about this in
common terms but actually each Major mobile platform maintains its own mobile
push notification service that you have to interact with if you want to send push notifications to apps running on
those devices and each platform has its own API each platform has its own style and
rules of the road in terms of feedback and each platform has its own
features and functionality that you can take advantage of but as you start to think across these different platforms
you start to be you start to have to think about your Apple customers as a separate cohort from your Kindle Fire
customers and a separate cohort from your Google customers so whereas you'd like to think of them as one large group
you're forced to deal with them quite differently and you're forced to do three times the work now later on to this that your app
will hopefully have more than three users on three platforms you'd like to get to tens of millions of users or even
higher hundreds of millions and our customers have told us that when they run crossplatform apps and send push
notifications across those platforms to multiple multiple providers of devices
from Apple and Google and Kindle Fire this work gets even more complex you've
now got to maintain three separate connections to three separate push notification Services all with their own
feedback their own apis and their own functionality and so what developers
very often do today is they WR their own intermediary services that sit between
the cloud application and the platform specific push relay services and the intermediary
Services have the very simple job but very important job to abstract the differences between those apis so that
one message can be directed easily for example to Apple and Google and Kindle Fire and also to manage the feedback so
that that work can be centralized and you can solve that problem only once and
so instead of this picture the developers get this
picture and this makes their life easier because now they can have the abstraction that they didn't have before
and they can treat all of their customers as one large base and they
don't have to worry about the token management provided that they've solved
it correctly the first time but solving this problem actually introduces still more problems even
though the push notification services from Apple and Google and Amazon are
free in the sense that they don't charge developers to use them now you've built
this intermediary service that does involve cost and Dove does involve development and operational
complexity plus the scalability of that intermediary takes work so when you
launch with just a few dozen users and quickly scale to hundreds of millions of users not only do you have to scale the
core Cloud app you now have to scale your intermediary
application and so at every step of the way we've solved a set of problems
around push notifications but we've introduced new operational complexity and new
costs and so our customers have asked us to make this a little bit easier for them a little bit simpler and so that's
why we've extended the Amazon simple notification service with mobile push
which supports mobile push notifications to Apple Google and Kindle Fire
devices and SNS is a managed scalable crossplatform intermediary service in
the cloud that you can just use and you don't need to worry about how many messages will I send how quickly will I
send them and what apis will I use so let's talk about this in
depth we think of crossplatform notifications in one of two ways
sometimes you'd like to send one common message to all your users or to any cohort of your users and not worry about
what platform they're on and sometimes you'd like to take advantage of the particular pieces of
functionality that may exist for example increment the badge count on an iOS
device SNS makes it easy to do cross-platform push notifications in either of these cases if you like to
specify a platform specific payload you can do that and you can send the exact
API expression that you would ordinarily have sent directly to Apple's push notification service or Google's or
Amazon's on the other hand if you'd like to simplify the work that your Cloud application has to do you can simply
write the default generic message that you'd like to deliver to your customers
and SNS will transpose that cont content into the appropriate API payload for
each platform so we give you the ability to choose between the the automatic and the
manual if you will that gives you the balance of Simplicity and
flexibility we also give you a balance between very fine addressing and very
broad you can SNS itself has historically been a topic subscribe
model where you create a topic and attach subscribers to it and when you
publish that message is delivered as identical copies to each subscriber you can do that today with
SNS mobile push you can create subscribers to a topic from any platform and you can
address a single push notification to very many end devices at
once alternatively if you like to send unique messages to each recipient you
can you can direct those messages all the way down to the individual token
level so that you can say John you have an update in your game it's your turn to play and the content itself can be
targeted to me with my name can be targeted based on the circumstances that are in my account and the information
that is personally relevant to me so we balance this ability to be very fine and
very Broad in the choices that you have in using SN S mobile
push we've also simplified the token feedback and management process so that
you don't need to worry about it anymore SNS consumes the token feedback
from Apple and Google and Kindle Fires push notification platforms so that if
there is an update to the Token for particular device we either proactively
disable that token or swap token and you don't need to worry about it you are left with a single stable endpoint that
you can send notifications to without worrying that your future notifications may become delayed or blocked
entirely some customers tell us that even when we manage the feedback on
their behalf they would like to receive that information for their own Upstream
logic and so you can actually access the feedback information that we receive from Apple and Google and handle fire
but you don't have to use it in order to use
SNS now as I mentioned mobile push is built into the simple notification service which has been around since 2010
and that gives us a backbone that is highly scalable and highly efficient and
battle tested so it means that with SNS mobile push you can seamlessly go from
just a few messages or just a few devices up to hundreds of Millions and there's no provisioning there's no
management you just simply start using it more uh and you're able to do that
without sacrificing the delivery reliability or the durability and so you're able to trust
that your message will get where it's meant to
go we've worked hard to make it easy to get started with SNS mobile push and for
us and for many of our customers it starts with a console experience that lets you register your app that you've
created and what we've done is we've worked hard to make it so that you can take exactly the credentials and exactly
the files that you receive from Apple or from Google or from kindlefire and you
can drop those into our console and we will extract the information that we need in order to
address notifications to your users and that's one simple workflow you
can use for any platform that you might like to Target
it's simple to create a new app with SNS it's also simple to migrate an existing app you can grab the tokens that may
have been previously managed in your own intermediary service that you built and
you can very easily drop those into SNS to begin sending push notifications with
our service and and stop having to do that extra work
yourself because our customers tell us they want broad support for many
languages many platforms and sdks we've made sure that SNS mobile push comes out of the box with uh all the sdks and all
the platforms and all the idees that AWS customers rely on so it's really easy to
get started and an additional piece of information that that our customers have
been really excited about is that you can get started sending mobile push notifications with SNS for free uh every
customer and everywhere every region in the world gets to send 1 million mobile
push notifications for free every month and after that you pay a dollar
for every million mobile push notifications so our research shows that
and our customers tell us that very many apps will never send more than that in a
particular month until they achieve scale and so this is something that's really excited that we're able to uh
we're able to offer to our customers so that's our quick intro to
SNS mobile push to sum up what we've spoken about SNS mobile push is a
crossplatform mobile push notifications service with support for Apple Google and Amazon devices you can get started
for free sending 1 million mobile push notifications every month and one mill
uh $1 per million after that we offer seamless scalability dur probability and
reliable deliveries and easy token management we've got some links here
that you can refer to to access our documentation and our detail page follow up by email if you have any any
questions you'd like to engage with us about but now we've left some time for questions so it looks like we have some
questions already some discussion going in the chat room and let's have a look and see what's worth speaking about
online
so one question is is there support for mobile push notifications to HTML 5 apps
today and the answer is we don't support that yet uh HTML 5 apps would have to
have a connection to the Apple or Google or Kindle Fire mobile push notification
services and they don't uh in some of these cases you can use those push notifications to
send to send messages to desktops through for example the Chrome browser
or Mac OS and you can have a look at that and where the Apple Google and kindlefire Push Services support desktop
today so does SNS
okay thank you very much for the feedback let's have a look at the other questions
so we have a question about easy token management somebody asks when you say easy token management does that mean
you'll be able to send us the token details of each user that opens the push notification so let's talk about how
token management works and what it means the token represents a particular app on
a particular device and it's your security credential that lets you send notifications to that device and it
means that uh it's information that without SNS you have to track and if the user
deletes the app you have to remove that token proactively from your database else the notifications will become
delayed or blocked SNS does that work for you and that's what we mean by easy token
management so I have another question is it possible to direct publishing based on a certain version of the application
running on the device uh the answer is yes that would be possible if you're able to collect
when you register your app for push notifications the first time a user runs it you're able to record in your
database information that gets associated with the SNS endpoint so for
example if you wanted to register which version of the app the user was using
and update that as the user updated his app you could create an SNS topic that would have all users that use
a particular version of the app and you could send them notifications alternatively if you had
in your database a field that says here is the name and handle of my user and
here's the version of the app that he's running you could run a query that gives you a list of addresses to send direct
publishes to and you could you could use publish a mobile push notification to all of those
users we have another question about token management uh how can users use
it uh so we actually do have sample code in our documentation and you can use the
getting started guide and the docs that are linked on the page you see here but the good news would be that you actually
don't have to use token management at all it just works and so we do that proactively on your
behalf in the documentation you'll see some information about how to access the token feedback if you'd like to use
it for some other uh for some other purpose in addition to swapping and
disabling the tokens in order to keep sending push notification successfully
so we have a question about what is the format of the mobile push notifications
that get sent and it's a two-part question and I'll
answer that first part first each platform has a specific format that it
requires push notifications to be sent and that is a a Json blob that includes
a message payload and switches of apis such as are you going to increment the
badge or play a custom sound and so SNS will actually wrap your
message in the appropriate API for each platform or alternatively you can
specify exactly what is the API argument that you'd like to send to Apple to Google to Kindle
Fire if you'd like to tailor the format and tailor the functionality that you
use the second question is when push notifications are delivered can the name
of the sender be customized and the return response be analyzed on a keyword
basis the answer is yes you can customize the content of a mobile push
notification to the recipient and so you can say John your ticket is ready uh by
using direct publishing
okay so we have a question about the latency how long will it take to send
100,000 or a million notifications we don't publish
performance numbers today but I can tell you that SNS overall
handles several billion messages of various endpoint
types every day and so we're really pleased with the performance uh you
should let us know if you have a particular requirement for your use case you can follow up by email or
alternatively if you run into a limit that constraints
you we have another question to confirm we ourselves do not
have to manage the device tokens is that right yes that's
right we have question about scheduling how can I schedule mobile push notifications that I
send the answer is that you would have to code that logic in your application SNS is a a
transport today so when you hand us the message we will hand it directly over to
Apple and so what you would do is you would code into your app the timing that
would pull the list of devices to send a message to and the particular message
that you'd like to
send we have a question about if I want to send a push notification to 1 million
not 1 million devices do I have to do 1 million API calls uh it depends how you use it the
most common way to do this today would be to send 1 million publishes and 1
million deliveries excuse me 1 million publishes and 1 million deliveries
to address those 1 million devices in total that would cost you
$1 if you use SNS topics to group the devices that you'd like to
send messages to your effective price can be lower because you'll pay for only one publish against however many
deliveries you do in the topic and today our topics allow
something like 10,000 uh 10,000 subscribers for individual topics so
that would mean you would only have one publish against 10,000 deliveries and your effective price would be
significantly lower than $1 per
million question is how can I deal with large dynamic recipient groups uh if I want to send messages to
large numbers of recipients can I manage the topics directly or do I have to to
do direct publishing the answer is that you have a choice you can use SNS topics
and you can dynamically manipulate the subscribers to those
topics but if the uh depending on how how fast is the change of the makeup and
how custom will be the message for each recipient you could choose to use either
broadcast with SNS topics or direct publishing
we have a question about is SNS does SNS add additional
reliability beyond what Google and apple and Amazon offer and the answer is no
the uh reliability and the durability of SNS is about getting the message to
Google and apple and the Kindle Fire relay service and uh those services are
are quite reliable in practice but they don't offer
slas ah here's a question about can is there a user interface a console that
can be used to create and send messages or is this API only the answer is that SNS offers a
Management console it's integrated with the AWS Management console and in
addition to setting up new apps with the console you can also send push
notifications either a default message or platform specific push
notifications you can also use the console to create and manage topics and
apps so here's a question about where are the push
notifications themselves generated and this is this is sort of related to
our previous question that we just answered uh you can either create the message yourself within your own app and
send it via API to SNS which is what we understand many of our customers want to
do you can also create a message from within the SNS Management console so we
give you a choice there here's a question with SN will I
no longer need to store tokens in my database and the answer
is you will want to store the tokens themselves in your database because it will make it easier to address the
messages that you'd like to send however you no longer need to proactively update the tokens in your
database you can simply keep a list of the users and the SNS endpoints that
you'd like to address and SNS will manage the tokens underneath those user endpoints so it'll make it
easier let's see looking through the
questions does this come with analytics what information can I get about successes and
failures so today SNS mobile push is fully integrated with Amazon cloudwatch
you can use it to get information about whether the notifications were delivered successfully to Apple and Google and
Kindle Fire um and you can look at that on a per message basis or overall and
you can set alarms about it and you can set alerts about it uh this is the information that the platform providers
send back and and we in turn hand that on to you so what it doesn't include is
whether the message itself was opened or whether the user took an action based on that if you wanted to build that you
would have to write that logic directly into your
app looking at questions
here can you send a message based on the user's location and the answer is that
you would need to use a geol location package within your within your app that
tracks the current location of the user and send notifications based on that
that's not functionality we offer today however if you have that information you can use it to create a
Target list and send notifications to a particular group of
users there's a question about how many SNS topics can be created per developer
account uh today we have a soft limit of I believe it's 3,000 topics per developer account uh which developers
tell us is more than they they would need for a lot of use cases but if you need more you should email us and we can
increase that limit for
you here's a question about responses to push notifications after a user receives
a push notification can he or she directly respond and can that response be
directed and the answer is that push notifications themselves are most
unidirectional meaning the user will receive them on her device she can choose to acknowledge it and open the
app you can then code the ability for her to respond directly so there can be
an email window that opens or some other Communications channel that allows you to communicate in real time but that
would be another another piece of technology it wouldn't be related to the push notification
got a couple questions about what uh plans we have for additional platform support in the future some people have

feedback we're always trying to figure out what is the right road map that our customers
would benefit from the
most so we have a question about the security of SNS and the confidentiality
of messages sent using the service uh the answer would be that
while the message is within the AWS platform it conforms to the security
security standards that AWS follows and we've written what we believe are the
best practices for locking down access to publishing push notifications and
registering new devices however Amazon doesn't control
the push relay Services of Apple and Google and the Kindle Fire push notification service is not uh not part
of SNS so the those are those are public services that you're using and so you should
consider accordingly what information you're going to send down those
channels here's a question about about live scores notification for live scores for
example breaking headlines or in a in a sports game uh they only make sense if
they're delivered in a matter of SEC of seconds can SNS be used in this scenario and we see this that this is a
very common scenario for mobile push notifications typically when we talk about latency and delivery times uh they
can be sort of variable within the terms of computer time but quite fast in human
time so that a human would perceive that the push notifications are delivered in a matter of
seconds we have a question about SMS um SMS support within
SNS so to articulate that text message support within simple notification
service in addition to sending mobile push notifications for Apple and Google
and fire devices simple notification service also supports text messages and
just as you're targeting push notifications you can also Target text messages today within the
US and so uh if some of your users are on feature phones that might be a a good
additional channel for you to reach
them so uh I have a question about exactly how the free tier is set the
free tier is a combination of two free tiers actually you you have uh 1 million
free publishes and 1 million free deliveries and so if you use SNS topics
to group deliveries against one publish you would uh use up your
delivery your free deliveries faster than your free publishes
we have a question about code samples are there currently clear code samples using SNS with apple push notifications
and the answer is yes uh you can use the link on the slide that you see on the screen here and actually download not

sending push notifications right away
here's a question about developing for apple on the same theme uh how can SNS
mobile push handle development versus production push tokens for
APNs the answer is that Apple has separate Push Services for apps that are in development versus apps that are in
the App Store and are in production and so we actually treat those as separate
push relay services and so what you would do is you would register your Beta app as one app within SNS and you would
re-register it within SNS as a production app and you would associate the
production tokens to the production
app I have a question about the message size If the message size exceeds the limit do we automatically break up the
message uh and the answer is that we handle this in one of two ways each mobile platform has a
different limit to it to the payload size that it will support and so if you
send a default message SNS will do its best to deliver that message in the way that is most appropriate for each
platform and what it will do is it'll chop off any piece of the message that
is longer than what is allowed for that platform alternatively if you send a
plat for specific payload where you tell us exactly what to relay to Apple or Google or candle fire you'll get an
error If the message is too big because the instruction would be
invalid so I have a question about what are the costs of using SMS versus inapp
notifications mobile po notifications are significantly cheaper then SMS text messages just as they're
uh well it's based on the fact that you use data either Wii or cellular to
deliver push notifications versus SMS which is typically charged differently if you have a look at our
detail page aws.amazon.com [Music] SNS you'll see what are the the costs
for each of these delivery methods
here's a question about what are the credentials and we've seen a few questions like this what credentials are
required to send mobile push notifications and Is this different from
the user credentials of a particular device and the answer is that yes you
can create uh you can use your AWS login
your AWS credentials to authorize your Cloud app to send uh mobile push
notifications via our API or you can use your AWS credentials to log into the
console and send notifications that way so this is restricted so that only you
as the developer can send messages to your customers your customers would not be able to send push notifications to
other customers through
SNS there's a question about about how long a notification can be held if the device
is offline the way that works is each platform will hold the messages for a
different period of time and they'll hold a different number of messages depending on which platform you're
talking about so you can use our documentation to find the links to Apple
and Google and Kindle Fire specifics uh but the answer is those
platforms will hold your message for some period of time if the user's device is off or he's out of the country and if
the user is gone for longer than that period of time they may interpret that
the guy has deleted his app or stop using that device
entirely so we've seen a few questions about opting in to push notifications
and how does SNS abstract from that the answer is that when a user first runs
his app or in some cases downloads the app he'll be asked to opt in are you
willing to receive push notifications and only when he clicks yes is the original token
generated and then sent up to SNS so the fact that you have a token
means that the user has opted in to receive messages and if in future that
user opts out and no longer wishes to receive messages the token will become invalid
and SNS will disable it in response to feedback so we'll manage that for you one best practice that we've seen is
to offer a setting within your own app that provides granular control over
which type of push notifications a user wants to receive for example a new message for me or a new offer for
me or a new message to one of my friends I might have different levels of
interest in each of those types of content and so if you provide users with control over the particular kinds of
messages that they're going to receive you're going to make them happier to receive the messages that they do get

way we have a couple of people seconding the feature request for a uh a batch

in order to use SNS it's your choice you can use the sdks and librar that we
provide or you can use HTTP calls to send messages and send content to us
directly that's your choice I have a question about security
policies about who can send messages to my devices and what uh what policies I

the token policy product called am within AWS and
so you can set I am credentials that have narrowly scoped permissions to send

commands we have a couple of people asking for confirmations about the free
tier that SNS offers every account can send up to 1 million mobile push

would be split across the multiple apps
got a bunch more questions
